title: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure - Rule 56 Summary Judgment Analysis
summary: Comprehensive analysis of summary judgment standards under Rule 56, including the burden of proof, genuine disputes of material fact, and the standard of review applied by courts.
keyFindings: Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. The burden is on the moving party to establish the absence of a genuine issue.
citations: Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242 (1986)
relevantCases: Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp.
author: Sarah Mitchell

title: Delaware Corporate Law - Fiduciary Duties of Directors in M&A Transactions
summary: Analysis of Revlon duties and the enhanced scrutiny standard applied to board decisions in change of control transactions under Delaware law.
keyFindings: When a board decides to sell the company, directors must act as auctioneers to maximize shareholder value. The board's duty changes from the preservation of the corporate entity to the maximization of the company's value at a sale.
citations: Revlon, Inc. v. MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, Inc., 506 A.2d 173 (Del. 1986)
relevantCases: Paramount Communications Inc. v. QVC Network Inc.
author: Michael Chen

title: ERISA Section 502(a) - Breach of Fiduciary Duty Claims
summary: Examination of civil enforcement provisions under ERISA, focusing on claims for breach of fiduciary duty and available remedies.
keyFindings: ERISA provides a comprehensive civil enforcement scheme allowing participants and beneficiaries to bring actions for breach of fiduciary duty. Remedies include equitable relief, plan reformation, and surcharge.
relevantCases: LaRue v. DeWolff, Boberg & Associates, Inc.
author: Jennifer Lopez

title: Patent Infringement - Doctrine of Equivalents Analysis
summary: Analysis of the doctrine of equivalents in patent infringement cases, including the function-way-result test and prosecution history estoppel.
keyFindings: Under the doctrine of equivalents, a product or process that does not literally infringe may still be found to infringe if it performs substantially the same function in substantially the same way to obtain substantially the same result.
citations: Graver Tank & Mfg. Co. v. Linde Air Products Co., 339 U.S. 605 (1950)
relevantCases: Warner-Jenkinson Co. v. Hilton Davis Chemical Co.
Festo Corp. v. Shoketsu Kinzoku Kogyo Kabushiki Co.
author: David Kim

title: Title VII Disparate Impact - Griggs Standard and Employer Defenses
summary: Comprehensive review of disparate impact theory under Title VII, including the Griggs v. Duke Power framework and business necessity defense.
keyFindings: Facially neutral employment practices that have a disproportionate adverse impact on protected groups violate Title VII unless the practice is job-related and consistent with business necessity.
citations: Griggs v. Duke Power Co., 401 U.S. 424 (1971)
relevantCases: Wards Cove Packing Co. v. Atonio
author: Amanda Rodriguez

title: Securities Act Section 11 - Material Misstatement Liability
summary: Analysis of Section 11 liability for material misstatements or omissions in registration statements, including available defenses.
keyFindings: Section 11 imposes strict liability on issuers for material misstatements in registration statements. Non-issuer defendants may establish a due diligence defense by demonstrating reasonable investigation.
citations: Escott v. BarChris Construction Corp., 283 F. Supp. 643 (S.D.N.Y. 1968)
relevantCases: In re WorldCom, Inc. Securities Litigation
author: Steven Park

title: HIPAA Privacy Rule - Permitted Disclosures for Treatment, Payment, and Operations
summary: Detailed analysis of permitted uses and disclosures of protected health information under the HIPAA Privacy Rule without patient authorization.
keyFindings: Covered entities may use and disclose PHI for treatment, payment, and healthcare operations without patient authorization, subject to the minimum necessary standard.
author: Dr. Maria Garcia

title: Fair Housing Act - Reasonable Accommodation Requirements for Disabled Tenants
summary: Analysis of landlord obligations to provide reasonable accommodations for disabled tenants under the Fair Housing Act.
keyFindings: Landlords must make reasonable accommodations in rules, policies, practices, or services when necessary to afford disabled persons equal opportunity to use and enjoy a dwelling. The accommodation must not impose undue financial or administrative burden.
relevantCases: United States v. California Mobile Home Park Management Co.
author: Rachel Green

title: Bankruptcy Code Section 363 - Sale of Assets Outside Ordinary Course
summary: Examination of Section 363 sales in bankruptcy proceedings, including good faith purchaser protections and appeal rights.
keyFindings: Section 363(b) allows debtors to sell property outside the ordinary course of business after notice and hearing. Good faith purchasers receive strong protections, including mooting of appeals if the sale order is not stayed.
citations: In re Lionel Corp., 722 F.2d 1063 (2d Cir. 1983)
author: Christopher Lee

title: Environmental Law - CERCLA Liability and Innocent Landowner Defense
summary: Analysis of liability under CERCLA (Superfund) and the innocent landowner defense for contaminated property acquisitions.
keyFindings: CERCLA imposes strict, joint and several liability on current owners of contaminated property. The innocent landowner defense requires demonstrating appropriate inquiry into previous ownership and uses prior to acquisition.
relevantCases: United States v. Fleet Factors Corp.
Redwing Carriers, Inc. v. Saraland Apartments
author: Brian Anderson

title: Trademark Dilution - Famous Mark Protection Under Lanham Act Section 43(c)
summary: Comprehensive analysis of federal trademark dilution law, including fame requirements, blurring and tarnishment theories, and available defenses.
keyFindings: The Trademark Dilution Revision Act protects famous marks from uses that blur or tarnish their distinctiveness, even in the absence of consumer confusion. Fame must be national in scope.
citations: Moseley v. V Secret Catalogue, Inc., 537 U.S. 418 (2003)
relevantCases: Louis Vuitton Malletier S.A. v. Haute Diggity Dog, LLC
author: Jessica Taylor

title: California Labor Code Section 226.7 - Meal and Rest Break Penalties
summary: Analysis of California's strict meal and rest break requirements and the premium pay penalties for non-compliance.
keyFindings: Employers must provide 30-minute meal breaks and 10-minute rest breaks at specified intervals. Failure to provide compliant breaks requires payment of one hour of premium pay at the employee's regular rate.
relevantCases: Brinker Restaurant Corp. v. Superior Court
Augustus v. ABM Security Services, Inc.
author: Kevin Martinez

title: Federal Arbitration Act - Unconscionability and Class Action Waivers
summary: Review of Supreme Court jurisprudence on arbitration agreements, particularly enforceability of class action waivers in consumer and employment contexts.
keyFindings: The FAA preempts state laws that single out arbitration agreements for disfavored treatment. Class action waivers in arbitration agreements are generally enforceable, even if they prevent effective vindication of federal statutory rights.
citations: AT&T Mobility LLC v. Concepcion, 563 U.S. 333 (2011)
Epic Systems Corp. v. Lewis, 138 S. Ct. 1612 (2018)
author: Angela White

title: GDPR Article 6 - Lawful Basis for Processing Personal Data
summary: Analysis of the six lawful bases for processing personal data under GDPR, with focus on consent and legitimate interests grounds.
keyFindings: Controllers must identify and document a lawful basis before processing personal data. Consent must be freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous. Legitimate interests require balancing test considering data subject rights.
author: Sophie Mueller

title: New York CPLR Section 3212 - Summary Judgment Motion Practice
summary: Detailed analysis of New York's summary judgment procedures, including timing requirements, burden of proof, and standards for opposition.
keyFindings: Moving party must make prima facie showing of entitlement to judgment as a matter of law through admissible evidence. Burden then shifts to opponent to demonstrate existence of triable issues of fact.
citations: Zuckerman v. City of New York, 49 N.Y.2d 557 (1980)
relevantCases: Zuckerman v. City of New York
author: Robert Jackson
